fault.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: if something bad that has happened is your fault, you should be blamed for it, because you made a mistake or failed to do something
fault.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I’m really sorry – it’s all my fault.
I didn’t sleep well that night, but it was my own fault.
It’s my fault for not making your new job clearer.
be somebody’s fault for doing something
fault.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: something that is wrong with a machine, system, design etc, which prevents it from working properly
fault.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: It sounds as if there’s a fault in one of the loudspeakers.
fault.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: something that is wrong with something, which could be improved
fault.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: There are two serious faults in Hobsbawm’s discussion of nationalism.
For all its faults (=in spite of its faults) we love this city.
fault.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a mistake in the way that something was made, which spoils its appearance
fault.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The sweater had a fault in it and I had to take it back.
fault.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a bad or weak part of someone’s character
fault.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: His worst fault is his arrogance.
I may have my faults, but ingratitude is not one of them.
For all his faults (=in spite of his faults) he was a good father.
fault.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a large crack in the rocks that form the Earth’s surface
fault.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: a mistake made when a player is serving the ball in tennis
fault.translation[0].note_box[0].section: something wrong
fault
a problem in a machine, system, design etc that causes damage or makes it not work properly
The fire was caused by an electrical fault.
a fault in the engine
defect
a fault in something such as a product or machine, resulting from the way it was made or designed
Cars are tested for defects before they leave the factory.
a part of a plan, system, or argument that is not as good as the other parts, and makes it likely to fail
What are the strengths and weaknesses of each method?
flaw
a fault in a plan, system, argument etc, especially one that makes it useless or not effective
Your argument has a fundamental flaw.
There was one major flaw in his suggestion – we didn’t have enough money.
bug
a fault in a computer program
A bug in the system was quickly fixed.
glitch
a small fault in the way something works, that can usually be easily corrected
I noticed a small glitch when installing the software.
mistake
something that is wrong in someone’s spelling, grammar, calculations etc
The article was full of spelling mistakes.
there’s something wrong with something
used when saying that there is a problem in a machine, car etc, but you do not know what it is
There’s something wrong with the computer – it won’t close down.
fault.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to criticize someone or something for a mistake
fault.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: You might not like O'Donnel’s arrogance, but it’s hard to fault what he does on the field.
it is hard/difficult to fault somebody/something
The judge cannot be faulted on his decision.
fault.translation[1].definitions[0].note: Fault is often used in the passive
fault.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: something that is wrong with a machine, system etc that prevents it from working correctly
fault.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Soviet engineers identified 32 design faults in the reactor, any of which could have led to an explosion.
fault.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: a mistake in the way something is made, that spoils its appearance
fault.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: The sweater had a fault in it and I had to take it back.
fault.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: the responsibility of a person or organization for damage or injury to someone, or for a criminal act
fault.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The borrowers were at fault for signing fraudulent applications.
fault.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: used to talk about arrangements where it is not necessary to prove that someone was at fault for the person who was injured or hurt to receive money
fault.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: no-fault systems for medical malpractice cases that would provide limited but guaranteed benefits
